study.title: Surgical Site Infections and Prophylaxis Antibiotic Use in the Surgical Ward of Public Hospital in Western Ethiopia: A Hospital-Based Retrospective Cross-Sectional Study

design.inclusion_criteria_text: All medical records of surgical patients admitted from 1st June 2019 to 31st May 2020 for elective or emergency surgical procedures with complete medical records were included.
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Medical records that did not have complete information, such as list of surgical antibiotics prophylaxis, were excluded.

country_specific_sites: Finote Selam General Hospital, Finote-Selam town, Northwest Ethiopia

eligibility.population: All patients admitted for elective or emergency surgical procedures at Finote Selam General Hospital from 1st June 2019 to 31st May 2020 with complete medical records.
eligibility.intervention: Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis regimens (ceftriaxone, metronidazole, cloxacillin, gentamicin, ciprofloxacillin)
eligibility.comparator: No prophylactic antibiotics, inappropriate use, alternative regimens

populations.description: All surgical patients admitted for elective or emergency procedures at FSGH during study period

provenance.text_snippet: In this study, 281 patients were assessed for SSI and appropriateness of surgical antibiotic prophylaxis use.

definitions.outcome_definitions_text: SSI defined as infection occurring at or near surgical incision within 30 days of operation or after one year in case of implant.

provenance.text_snippet: The present study showed that 19.6% (95% CI: 18–21.1) of patients developed SSIs.
Of the developed SSI, 14.5%, 3% and 3% involved superficial, deep, and organ structures, respectively (Figure 1).
Of the developed SSI, 14.5%, 3% and 3% involved superficial, deep, and organ structures, respectively (Figure 1).
Of the developed SSI, 14.5%, 3% and 3% involved superficial, deep, and organ structures, respectively (Figure 1).

length_of_stay.notes: Preoperative and postoperative duration of hospitalization reported in categories only.

provenance.text_snippet: Preoperative duration of hospitalization ≤1 day: 74.0%; >1 day: 26.0%. Postoperative duration: 1 day: 3.2%; 2 days: 40.2%; 3 days: 45.6%; 4 days: 11%.

risk_factors_effects.notes: Significant association between comorbidity and SSI.

provenance.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections
provenance.text_snippet: presence of comorbidity (AOR=9.18, 95% CI: 5.17–17.9, p<0.001)

risk_factors_effects.notes: Contaminated wounds associated with increased SSI risk.

provenance.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections

risk_factors_effects.notes: Dirty wounds associated with increased SSI risk.

provenance.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections

risk_factors_effects.notes: Not receiving prophylactic antibiotics associated with increased SSI risk.

provenance.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections
provenance.text_snippet: devoid of prophylactic antibiotics (AOR=6.63, 95% CI: 1.89–19.3, p=0.006)

risk_factors_effects.exposure: Timing of prophylactic antibiotic administration between 1 hour and 2 hours before incision
risk_factors_effects.notes: Timing of SAP 1–2 hours before incision associated with increased SSI risk.

provenance.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections
provenance.text_snippet: timing of prophylactic antibiotic administration between 1 hour and 2 hours before incision (AOR=8.2, 95% CI: 4.34–18.1, p=0.001)

risk_factors_effects.exposure: 48 hours duration of surgical antimicrobial prophylaxis
risk_factors_effects.notes: 48 hours SAP duration associated with increased SSI risk.

provenance.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections
provenance.text_snippet: 48 hours duration of surgical antimicrobial prophylaxis (AOR=7.20, 95% CI: 1.23–28.17, p=0.027)

interventions.description: Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis regimens including ceftriaxone, metronidazole, cloxacillin, gentamicin, ciprofloxacillin; timing and duration assessed for appropriateness.
interventions.comparator: No prophylactic antibiotics or inappropriate use

provenance.text_snippet: Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis was administered for more than three-fourth of patients (88.6%).

stewardship_guidelines.guideline_name: WHO SAP guidelines; American Society of Health-System Pharmacists, Infectious Diseases Society of America, Surgical Infection Society, Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America
stewardship_guidelines.adherence_definition: Appropriateness assessed by clinical pharmacists based on standard treatment guideline.
stewardship_guidelines.inappropriate_use_definition: Use of antibiotics not indicated, inappropriate choice, timing, dose, frequency, route, or duration.

provenance.text_snippet: Appropriateness of surgical antibiotic prophylaxis was assessed by clinical pharmacists based on the standard treatment guideline.

codes.summary: SSI prevalence was high (19.6%) among surgical patients at a tertiary hospital in Ethiopia.

evidence_quotes.quote: The present study showed that 19.6% (95% CI: 18–21.1) of patients developed SSIs.

provenance.text_snippet: The present study showed that 19.6% (95% CI: 18–21.1) of patients developed SSIs.

codes.summary: Inappropriate timing and duration of prophylactic antibiotics, and lack of adequate infection control systems, were identified as drivers of SSI.

evidence_quotes.quote: The higher prevalence of SSI in our setting could be due to the lack of adequate infection control systems, poor practices, and inappropriate use of antibiotics.

provenance.text_snippet: The higher prevalence of SSI in our setting could be due to the lack of adequate infection control systems, poor practices, and inappropriate use of antibiotics.

codes.summary: Adherence to recommended guidelines for SAP timing and duration is necessary to reduce SSI risk.

evidence_quotes.quote: Healthcare professionals should consider the above risk factors while they are undergoing surgical procedures. They should also adhere to the recommended treatment guideline to prescribe appropriate prophylactic surgical antibiotics.

provenance.text_snippet: They should also adhere to the recommended treatment guideline to prescribe appropriate prophylactic surgical antibiotics.

codes.summary: Ceftriaxone and metronidazole were the most frequently used prophylactic antibiotics; 7.2% of regimens were inappropriate.

evidence_quotes.quote: Ceftriaxone and metronidazole (45.4%), and ceftriaxone (33.3%) were the most frequently used prophylactic antibiotics. Of the prescribed antibiotics, 7.2% were inappropriate.

provenance.text_snippet: Ceftriaxone and metronidazole (45.4%), and ceftriaxone (33.3%) were the most frequently used prophylactic antibiotics.

codes.summary: There is a paucity of data on SSI and antibiotic use in Northwest Ethiopia.

evidence_quotes.quote: Although several studies have been conducted on SSIs, with significant variations in different regions, there was a paucity of data in the Northwest part of Ethiopia.

provenance.text_snippet: there was a paucity of data in the Northwest part of Ethiopia.
No risk of bias assessment reported.

provenance.text_snippet: Preoperative duration of hospitalization ≤1 day: 74.0%; >1 day: 26.0%. Postoperative duration: 1 day: 3.2%; 2 days: 40.2%; 3 days: 45.6%; 4 days: 11%.

provenance_index.text_snippet: In this study, 281 patients were assessed for SSI and appropriateness of surgical antibiotic prophylaxis use.
The present study showed that 19.6% (95% CI: 18–21.1) of patients developed SSIs.
Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis was administered for more than three-fourth of patients (88.6%).
Ceftriaxone and metronidazole (45.4%), and ceftriaxone (33.3%) were the most frequently used prophylactic antibiotics.

provenance_index.section_heading: Factors Associated with Surgical Site Infections

provenance_index.text_snippet: The higher prevalence of SSI in our setting could be due to the lack of adequate infection control systems, poor practices, and inappropriate use of antibiotics.
They should also adhere to the recommended treatment guideline to prescribe appropriate prophylactic surgical antibiotics.
there was a paucity of data in the Northwest part of Ethiopia.
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
